Review: Glass

21/01/2019

Image by

By James Bithell


6.5 / 10

Director: M. Night Shyamalan

Starring: James McAvoy, Bruce Willis, Samuel L. Jackson

Length: 2h 9min

Rating: PG-13


The release of Glass, the ending film in the trilogy containing Unbreakable (2000) and Split (2016) sees a spectacular performance from James McAvoy be slightly under-appreciated due to the subjectively unique story that is not necessarily a crowd pleaser. Personally, I felt the film was a very different and refreshing take on the subject of superheroes, and provides a plot that is filled with many a twist and turn that does keep you intrigued and guessing throughout the whole film. Although it does have its faults, which is mostly down to M. Night Shyamalan's ever decreasing finesse and success with his writing, the film is definitely one to be recommended despite critical reviews.


The story follows the brittle boned, superintelligent Mr. Glass (Samuel L. Jackson), the DID sufferer with 24 different personalities Kevin Crumb (James McAvoy) and the super strong David Dunn (Bruce Willis); as they are all institutionalised for being dangerous due to their psychological instability and the belief that they are superheroes. Overseen by Dr. Ellie Staple (Sarah Paulson), they are all monitored as she tries to convince them that their actions can be explained scientifically to curb their beliefs of their powers. Despite it taking half the film for Mr. Glass to do anything, he finally mastermindâ€™s a plan to help the three of them escape as he wants to stage a superhero battle to prove to the world that their existence is in fact a reality.


Now I must admit, there is A LOT more that happens in the film, as returning characters, twists, turns and reveals take over; so to enhance the cinematic experience a truly limited spoiler free summary is all you should read.


Personally, there were quite a lot of positives to the film and the distinct angle it takes towards the presentation of superheroes. It successfully creates an alternate depiction of these â€œheroesâ€ as being troubled and questioning of their own power; as well as being set up by higher powers to mirror comic book commonalities. The constant questioning of the audience of their powers is also very successful in creating an investment in the characters and their struggles as you yourself experience the same deciphering of the facts that the characters similarly go through. The highlight of the movie has to be James McAvoyâ€™s portrayal of Kevin Crumb and his ability to create almost two dozen different characters all rolled up into one, giving each one its little quirks so you know exactly what personality he is playing without them having to even acknowledge it. Glass also takes a different outlook of Crumb compared to his unnerving and disturbing characterisation in Split; as the audience leans more towards the sympathetic and supportive feeling towards his tribulations and sufferings. Without revealing anything, the twists that Shyamalan is known so well for are definitely present in Glass, with several landing successfully enough to make you respect the story and tone of the film just a little bit more.



However, the film is far from perfect. From the get go, with the tone set by Split you would expect Glass to be much more horror based than it is; as it comes across more of a (slightly) psychological action film to be honest. It also has some surprisingly dark humour that will make you unnervingly chuckle, which is not necessarily a bad thing, but is definitely unexpected. The story can also fall flat in some places, with the aim of trying to level out the parts of predictability with other twists further in the story which just is not how successful writing should work. In terms of acting, I felt that Bruce Willis completely flat-lined as he brought no emotion or personality to his character and even managed to make action sequences look boring. I also really want to be able to praise Sarah Paulson as I just always want to root for her, but her character was honestly a bit bland and did not receive the characterisation it should have done for the events that are set up by the twists at the end of the movie. Although it is not negative, such twists that occur can in some places be very confusing, leaving the audience with that disappointing feeling of, â€œI donâ€™t get itâ€. However, it takes sitting it out for all the questions to be answered and for everything to be truly understood; and I just wish that these twists were executed more effectively to remove that sense of disappointing confusion that can ruin the film for a viewer.


Despite some of the minor faults in the movie, overall Glass is enjoyable and engaging enough to warrant its place in the trilogy as a sequel. I would recommend at least seeing Split before the movie, however if you have not seen Unbreakable I would at least look up the plot summary of the film as it does help with the understanding of Glass. In a month of a lack of blockbusters or big budget movies being released, I would definitely suggest taking a cinema trip to go and see Glass.
